ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Spanish vocabulary, conjugations, present, future, subjunctive, imperative and other tenses. Cultural information about various Latin countries and customs.
I learned how to better speak Spanish, accent-wise but also in terms of vocabulary. This class also taught me a lot about the cultures of Spanish-speaking countries.
I bettered some of my Spanish.
I developed my speaking and writing skills in spanish.
Plenty of new spanish vocabulary and practice speaking, reading and writing.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I thought the class was not set up great. There should be more speaking in class.
The course is very poorly designed and the jump from L1 to L2 is far too great for beginner spanish learners.
The literature was good, the Flashcultura exercises in all honesty seemed like a waste of time.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, your level of spanish improves very quickly and you can have full conversations
This class greatly improved my spanish skills. I would definitely recommend it to anyone looking to increase Spanish proficiency.
Yes, I learned a lot and it was worth it, but it was time-consuming. The language will be helpful in the future due to its widespread use in this world.
I would not recommended the class to other students unless they were required to take it and had their mind set on spanish.
Yes. I love spanish so I'm quite biased but the professors in our spanish department seem to be very strong so I believe most people will have a good experience in the end.
